sub_topic: Finding the area under a curve using integration
message_1: The function f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 3x + 1 is defined on the interval [0,2]. Find the area under the curve of the function f(x) on the interval [0,2].
message_2:
To find the area under the curve of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 3x + 1 on the interval [0, 2], we need to integrate the function with respect to x from 0 to 2.

âˆ«(x^3 - 2x^2 + 3x + 1) dx from 0 to 2

First, we find the antiderivative of the function:

Antiderivative of x^3 is (1/4)x^4
Antiderivative of -2x^2 is (-2/3)x^3
Antiderivative of 3x is (3/2)x^2
Antiderivative of 1 is x

So, the antiderivative of the function is (1/4)x^4 - (2/3)x^3 + (3/2)x^2 + x

Now, we evaluate the antiderivative at the endpoints of the interval and subtract:

[((1/4)(2)^4 - (2/3)(2)^3 + (3/2)(2)^2 + (2)) - ((1/4)(0)^4 - (2/3)(0)^3 + (3/2)(0)^2 + (0))]

= [(1/4)(16) - (2/3)(8) + (3/2)(4) + 2]

= [4 - (16/3) + 6 + 2]

= [12 - (16/3)]

= [36/3 - 16/3]

= 20/3

So, the area under the curve of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 3x + 1 on the interval [0, 2] is 20/3 square units.
